node.title: How to apply identical displacements to both ends of a rectangular mesh
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
How can I apply identical displacements at both ends of a rectangular grid to create an arch-shaped deformation?
Do I need to establish a reference point with a displacement of 0? If so, where should this reference point be set?
Here is the schematic diagram:

Hello
Use a FunctionDirichletBC on both ends and slowly apply the displacement if you want to see the strain appear.
The transformation of the surface can be derived analytically if it's just an angle.
Guillaume

Do I need to fix the displacement of a reference point to zero when using a FunctionDirichletBC on both ends?
Currently, I've attempted to directly apply the ADNeumannBC boundary condition on the left and right boundaries and specified disp_z. I've used a steady solver, but it's not converging at all.

NeumannBC is not used to set a displacement, it's used to impose a force. You should use the Pressure action for that purpose.
If you only impose forces on the two ends, you do need to add dirichletBCs to remove extraneous translation / rotation dofs

I made a mistake previously; I applied force using the NeumannBC. My mesh is 3D. How should I eliminate or constrain the excess degrees of freedom to achieve convergence? Currently, my boundary conditions are set as follows:
[BCs]
[Load1]
type = ADNeumannBC
boundary = right
value = 0.05
variable = disp_z
[]
[Load2]
type = ADNeumannBC
boundary = left
value = 0.05
variable = disp_z
[]
[]

You could pick a surface in the mesh and apply 0 displacements there. For example the symmetry plane of the mesh?
If you are not going to constrain the disaplacement of the surface edges, this would work
Exactly, I don't need to restrict displacement.
Thanks for your advice

node.title: How does the capillary pressure affect MOOSE converge?
node.bodyText:
Greetings!
I recently engaged with the 1D injection porous flow example located in the Moose folder (modules/porous_flow/test/tests/fluidstate/theis_brineco2_nonisothermal.i). Specifically, I adjusted the length parameter from 200m to 100m within the [mesh] section and added capillary pressure . However, this alteration led to convergence issues. I'm now curious about the capillary pressure controlling convergence performance.
The changes:

  [pc] # type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureConst # pc = 0 type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG alpha = 5.099e-5 m = 0.457 sat_lr = 0.0 pc_max = 1e7 []
Results:

Thank you,

Hello
There's a page on porous flow converge issues if you want to check that out
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/tutorial_02.html

node.title: How to set integrated two-step simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi there!
I'd like to conduct a two-step simulation:
Step 1: Apply a displacement in the z-direction to the mesh on the right. Use a steady-state simulation to obtain the deformed mesh and related displacement variables.
Step 2: Read the displacements from the deformed mesh for subsequent calculations. At this point, displacements are coupled with other variables, and the calculations are transient.
How can I easily achieve this simulation? Is it possible to do it in a single input file?
Thanks in advance!

This kind of thing is commonly done with MOOSE. The steady and transient simulations will require two different inputs. I would recommend reading this page for a background on restart capabilities in MOOSE
Thank you for the recommendation!

node.title: mamba init & new Mac
node.bodyText:
Hello:
I just began the install process on a new Mac with Ventura 13.4.  All works well until the "mamba activate moose" step.  Then I get the
"Run 'mamba init' to be able to run mamba activate/deactivate
and start a new shell session. Or use conda to activate/deactivate."
message.  Note that this also happens for a "testing" environment as per the troubleshooting instructions.
I have deleted and re-installed mamba a number of time with the same results.  I pasted the following into my .zshrc file:
`# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!
__conda_setup="$('/Users/joe/mambaforge3/bin/conda' 'shell.zsh' 'hook' 2> /dev/null)"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    eval "$__conda_setup"
else
    if [ -f "/Users/joe/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh" ]; then
        . "/Users/joe/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh"
    else
        export PATH="/Users/joe/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup
# <<< conda initialize <<<

mamba activate moose

export HOST=$(hostname)`

My .condarc file is
`channels: [https://conda.software.inl.gov/public, conda-forge]

If I do a 'mamba info', I get:
(base) ~ % mamba info

Any suggestions?  Is there some way to completely begin anew? Or does this have to do with Mac OS 13.4?
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hello
So the issue that it s always asks for init even though you've done mamba init closed the terminal and re-opened already
You are working with zsh not bash right?

I get:

Run 'mamba init' to be able to run mamba activate/deactivate

and start a new shell session. Or use conda to activate/deactivate.
(base) ~ %
Note there is a 'mamba activate moose' in my .zshrc file.

can you paste a screenshot of a fresh new terminal?
mamba thinks you are using bash right now.
I killed terminal and then relaunched it.  The screenshot is attached.

(base) ~ % echo $0
-zsh

I have seen this before. And while everything looks like zsh, the system default is still set to BASH. I like to blame Apple on this, as even their instructions:
The default interactive shell is now zsh.
To update your account to use zsh, please run `chsh -s /bin/zsh`.
For more details, please visit https://support.apple.com/kb/HT208050.
...doesn't work. You have to do it using their GUI. That is, through System Preferences Ref: #24072 (reply in thread)
Can you verify that your default profile is Zsh? By way of using System Preferences, Users & Groups, Right-click on you, Advanced Options... and this is where it gets a little fuzzy for us. We no longer even have the ability to get this far, and leave screen shots for what we are trying to demonstrate.
Here is a screenshot.  It says zsh.

I just tried to source a mamba_init file.  Nothing changed.  The file is attached.
mamba_init.txt

Are you comfortable removing the entry Mamba added to your ~/.bash_profile? If so, lets do that... open a new term, see what happens.
I am asking that you remove this entire piece from ~/.bash_profile:
# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!

    else
        export PATH="/Users/joe/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup
# <<< conda initialize <<<
Apologies if you've done this already. I am just arriving to this thread.

Unfortunately.  No difference.  The steps I did:

quit terminal and reopen
mamba init
open a new terminal window
mamba activate moose, this again says to 'mamba init'

fi
<<< conda initialize <<<

I wrecked my brain for days on this. Until I stumbled upon this answer

I am using Intel MacBook Pro.

node.title: Obtain _grad_phi on boundary condition of an Array variable.
node.bodyText:
Greetings
I wish to implement $u \cdot \nabla u$ on a boundary for an array variable.
What I have in mind is I'll put
 _u[_qp] * _grad_u[_qp](component) * _test[_i][_qp]
for residual and put
_phi[_qp] * _grad_phi[_qp] * _test[_i][_qp]
for Jacobian, but when I'm trying to obtain the value of _grad_phi, with _grad_phi(_assembly.gradPhiFace(_var)), I failed. I keep getting an empty object. Did I make a mistake somewhere?
Thanks

hello
did you make sure _grad_phi is a reference in your new kernel?
what finite element family are you using?
Guillaume

actually this is a boundary condition right?
I think grad_phi on the face inside the domain would be discontinuous
Can you try to initialize it by retrieving a reference (or pointer) to the array variable and doing this:
_grad_phi(_var.gradPhiFace())

That's right, it's a boundary condition.
If I do _grad_phi(_var.gradPhiFace()) and watch _grad_phi[_qp] in debugger, it's no longer empty! Now it contains 4 elements and each element is a libMesh vector contains three doubles, with only one of them being nonzero. So I guess three of those four vector represent the gradient vector of the variable, then what would the remaining one be?

Are the 4 elements the 4 components of the array variable maybe?
You should Double check the indexing. I don't know that the qp index is the first one. Look for examples in the code

The array variable only contains one element,  I used array variable simply because it's easier to work with in terms of my customized kernels. I'll run through my code again and see if there're any missed errors.
Is there a case/test that involves  u * grad_u on boundary condition that I can refer to? That would be great.

There s not u grad_u but there are some examples of using grad_u and indexing into it.
There should be one in the DG kernels
Gotcha, thanks a lot!

@GiudGiud I spend a great amount of time on this BC but the solver still failed to converge. So I'm thinking about switching to Lagrange Multiplier and I just finished reading the AverageValueConstraint, which brings me another question: What's the difference between using Lagrange multiplier to enforce average value over the domain and actually implement $\int_\Omega u = V$ with residual (_u[_qp] * _JxW[_qp] * _coord[_qp]  - V) * _test[_qp] and Jacobian entries of (_phi[_qp] * _JxW[_qp] * _coord[_qp]  ) * _test[_qp]?

Hello
Before moving on, did you try the troubleshooting instructions there?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
There are instructions to check the Jacobian and other issues. For example if you are missing a part of the equation on part of the domain, the checks would find singular values, which cause convergence issues.

What's the difference between using Lagrange multiplier to enforce average value over the domain and actually implement
with residual (_u[_qp] * _JxW[_qp] * _coord[_qp]  - V) * _test[_qp] and Jacobian entries of (_phi[_qp] * _JxW[_qp] * _coord[_qp]  ) * _test[_qp]?

The lagrange multiplier adds another equation to the nonlinear system that gets solved simultaneously. The additional DOF of the Lagrange multiplier is used to write this equation. The average value will be enforced numerically, and should be converged with close to the solver nonlinear tolerance.
Using a boundary condition does not do that, it's adding the coefficients to the existing equations. The average value will only be enforced weakly, and will depend on the mesh discretization I think.

Before moving on, did you try the troubleshooting instructions there?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html

Thanks for pointing out! This is pretty helpful.

Using a boundary condition does not do that, it's adding the coefficients to the existing equations. The average value will only be enforced weakly, and will depend on the mesh discretization I think.

I implemented the kernel over the whole domain, I should have make that clear, but it's still not working. So I guess weak form of mean value constraint and Lagrange Multiplier are not the same.
But that brings another question: if I wish to constrain $\int_{\partial \Omega} u \nabla u = V$, where $\partial \Omega$ is the boundary of domain, with Lagrange Multiplier, I will have to implement a customize kernel right? I don't think there's a Lagrange Multiplier that takes a nonlinear constraint over the boundary in Moose.

node.title: BCs for a fixed-pressure 2D RZ channel flow
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts:
I'm learning Navier Stokes, and try to simulate a 2D symmetric channel flow which describe as follow:

Here's my input block using NavierStokesFV Action
[Modules]
  [NavierStokesFV]
    compressibility = 'weakly-compressible'
    add_energy_equation = true

    density = 'rho'
    dynamic_viscosity = 'mu'
    thermal_conductivity = 'k'
    specific_heat = 'cp'

    initial_temperature = 800
    initial_pressure = 900

    inlet_boundaries = 'right'
    momentum_inlet_types = 'fixed-pressure'
    momentum_inlet_function = 'boundary-pressure'
    energy_inlet_types = 'fixed-temperature'
    energy_inlet_function = 'boundary-temperature'

    wall_boundaries = 'top bottom left'
    momentum_wall_types = 'noslip noslip symmetry'
    energy_wall_types = 'heatflux heatflux heatflux'
    energy_wall_function = '0 0 0'
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [boundary-pressure]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '900 + 0.02 * y'
  []
  [boundary-temperature]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '800'
  []
[]

With complete input file
2d-rz-wcns.txt
The run converge well but I'm not sure if the boundary conditions are set correctly, because the results seems strange (as shown in left side of following picture, non-zero axial velocity on right boundary), and differs with result by COMSOL (shown in right, which seems more reasonable for me)

Could someone help to check my input?
Thanks in advance for help!

Hello
Why are you expecing non-zero velocity on the right boundary? It's a fixed pressure BC not a no-slip wall for velocity.
The fixed-pressure BC in MOOSE is coded for a fully-developed outlet boundary condition.
Can you draw streamlines in both codes? I wonder where the flow is going in the COMSOL simulation. It seems to flow down, but never up after, and it cant go through the symmetry BC so where does it go? Must be right
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume
I think for inlet on the right boundary, there should be only normal velocity and zero axial velocity. I don't know if I'm getting it right
Following is the streamline of both framework (MOOSE on the left-side)

And following is a comparison of the velocity components (MOOSE on the left-side)

Both results show that the working fluid flows from the upper-right high pressure region to the lower-right low pressure region (Pressure decreases linearly from top to bottom on the right boundary)
Difference seems to be that COMSOL specifies a normal flow direction at the pressure inlet while MOOSE does not

I think for inlet on the right boundary, there should be only normal velocity and zero axial velocity. I don't know if I'm getting it right

We don't impose this constraint on velocity in the fixed pressure BC.
You could add a dirichletBC on velocity_z to impose the 0 tangential velocity

Thanks for your suggestion, now the results are same. I didn't realize that I could add another BCs block outside Module block.
I still wonder if it's necessary to constrain a normal flux on a pressure BCs... Seems Commercial software like Fluent and Comsol have this by default, or artificially specify another flow direction. Possibly they do this for improving convergence.
maybe @grmnptr will know

node.title: Resolving ParsedFunction Scalar Limitation with Volumetric Stress in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hello, I hope you are doing great.
I'm encountering an issue while trying to activate a hot spot in my simulation based on the volumetric stress field (volstress) being below a certain threshold (0.015 GPa) within a specific region if((x--145.8797)^2+(y-130.4201)^2<(2.7977)^2,1,0). The volstress is calculated as a rank-two scalar auxiliary variable representing the hydrostatic stress.
[./volstress]
  type = RankTwoScalarAux
  rank_two_tensor = stress
  variable = volstress
  scalar_type = Hydrostatic
[../]

I've attempted to implement this using a ParsedFunction to define the activation criteria within the [Functions] section of my input file. However, I'm receiving an error indicating that the ParsedFunction only supports scalar variables, and volstress is not scalar.
Here's the relevant portion of my input file:
[Functions]
[source]
type = ParsedFunction
expression = '1e-2*(if(volstress < 0.015, if((x--145.8797)^2 + (y-130.4201)^2 < (2.7977)^2, 1, 0), 0))'
symbol_names = 'volstress'
symbol_values = 'volstress'
[]
[]
[Kernels]
[T_source]
type = HeatSource
variable = temperature
function = source
[]
[]
The error message suggests that ParsedFunction only accepts scalar variables (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/MooseParsedFunction.html). However, I need to use the volumetric stress value at each time step to determine when to activate the hot spot.
�[31m
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "source", of type "ParsedFunction".
The only variables supported by ParsedFunction are scalar variables, and var 'volstress' is not scalar.�[39m
How can I modify my approach to effectively use the volumetric stress value within the ParsedFunction while addressing this limitation?
Any advice or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. I'm also willing to provide additional information or code snippets if needed.
Thank you in advance for your assistance.
Best regards,
Alejandro

Hello
ParsedFunctions are meant to only depend on x y z and time, and some selected global variables like postprocessors.
Instead try to use a ParsedMaterial which can depend on variables.
Or a ParsedAux if you are NOT using AD (automatic differentiation)
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you so much for your fast response, I am going to try to implement the code with your suggestions. I will come back telling you how was it.
Best regards,
Alejandro.

node.title: Temperature coupling in phase field simulation of dendrite growth
node.bodyText:
I want to simulate the growth of lithium dendrite with phase field and study the influence of temperature on the growth morphology of dendrite. Through the literature, I know that I can couple the temperature with the diffusion rate of lithium ions. Is there any example about the influence of temperature on dendrite growth?


Looking forward to your reply, thank you!
@dschwen could you possibly help with this question?

We recently published an article that systematically analyzes the effect of different parameters during alloy solidification (it includes the temperature effect as well). You might find it useful.
https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1361-651X/ac46dc/meta
Thank you for your reply. I will study this article carefully!
thank you @SudiptaBiswas !

node.title: Moose will not install on HPC, cannot connect to github
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am new to this HPC/Sawtooth  and I am currenlty following this tutorial on installing moose on sawtooth:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/inl_hpc_install_moose.html
However; it seems like my terminal cannot access github to download moose. I have followed the instructions but cannot get past cloning moose. Here is what my terminal shows:
[eggejohn@sawtooth4 ~]$ qsub -I -P edu_res -l select=1:ncpus=20:mem=16gb -l walltime=1:00:00
qsub: waiting for job 1117673.sawtoothpbs to start
qsub: job 1117673.sawtoothpbs ready

(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 ~]$ module load use.moose moose-dev
(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 ~]$ mkdir -p ~/Sawtooth/projects
(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 ~]$ cd ~/Sawtooth/projects
(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 projects]$ clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
-bash: clone: command not found
(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 projects]$ git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
Cloning into 'moose'...
fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git/': Failed to connect to github.com port 443: Connection timed out
(base) [eggejohn@r3i1n14 projects]$ 

What are my next steps? I assume im doing something small worng with internet connection or something but my browser in the same interactive section can access the web. Should I do this in a login node or something?

Hello
compute nodes on sawtooth do not have access to the internet
You ll need to install on the head node
Guillaume
Ah thank you that fixed it. That's the opposite to what I am used too

node.title: Exporting element values into csv files
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear all,
I was wondering if there is any postprocessors or vector postprocessors that can exports element values for all the elements. Now I am doing it by Paraview, which it seems not to be the best way to do it specially for big meshes. Maybe something similar to LineValueSampler which reads a csv file of lines coordinates or ElementalVariableValue if it can be extended for the entire elements. I would appreciate it if you could help me. Thanks.

Hello
You mean this?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.html
Guillaume

Hi,
Thank you for the prompt response. Yes, that's exactly what I need. Thank you.
